38792220.review:
Fun and engaging, but fairly shallow for the price.

I was hoping for an experience that spawns from a queen and a few workers, into a sprawling colony that extends its territory all over the garden and scales that experience well enough to be fun in the early and late game, and hopefully offer some creativity in where the strategy fits into it.

You get the queen and some workers, but beyond that initial colony growth the game falls short of my dreams. The game gets choppy when you get a few dozen ants. You can get steamrolled on easy mode, while a match in one of the gamemodes I tried was lasting so long that I ended up quitting and going to bed.

The hive management feels simple and constrained, with the strategy being a basic numbers meta where you need to balance the workers/soldiers/food in a specific way to beat each level. My favorite RTS games are ones that feel like a creative outlet where plenty of playstyles can achieve victory, but Empires of the Undergrowth is not one of them.

I don't think it was worth the pricetag at £15.99, but with so few ants games around I can't hate a dev team for trying. I had some fun with it, and there's some cool mechanics that kept me engaged. While it's not the ant-covered garden I dream of, having a mad scientist accidentally drop a beetle into my ant tank felt like as good of a fight as any action game I've played.

38778041.review:
This game has a huge potential to become an amazing game.

It's obviously early access and still has a long way to go (especially in terms of content) but it has been fairly stable for me so far. There's a few bugs/glitches here and there but for an early access game the quality is pretty good (played far worse and only very few that were on par or better).

Currently there's only 3 ant species in the game, one that you use for your formicarium (a persistent sort of home base you can expand and return to after playing a scenario) and the two others you play in the scenarios. More are planed and more will come though.

The levels are fun to play and although the real AI hasn't made it into the first release it shows that the developers have a good understanding of level design and that you don't need advanced AI to make good scenarios (the proper AI is on it's way and acutally fairly far developed, it just wasn't required for the early access levels for which scripting was fully sufficient so it's development was delayed in favor of other things that actually were required for the early access release, like mostly fixing bugs that sprung up during the closed beta test to get a most stable and bugfree release client).

I applaud the developers for NOT going with the general "just smash everything that isn't you color" theme RTS games seem to favor these days but instead giving us four VERY different scenarios with interesting objectives and different gameplay (clearing an underground map, fending off invading slave-maker ants that steal your brood, surviving against the environment and variosu critters for three days on a beach with rising and falling tide, surviving an Onslaught of two ant colonies trying to take over your nest before their own nests on the lower levels get flooded).
I'm looking forward to the next scenarios (potentially with leafcutter ants) which will undeoubtatedly be quite different again.

Another thing I really love about this game is the way units move. This is NOT StarCraft where you can micromanage every single to the point of playing a tabletop game, this game is about MACRO.
Each of your unit groups (ants from connected nesting tiles are automatically put into one squad and you can put multiple of these squads into a group) can be called to a position by placing a pheromone marker. About half of the ants will react isntantly to the marker, more will follow it over time. This may seem annoying at first but once you've understood how this system works when fog of war gets implemented you'll appreciate it as it basically gives you full line of sight over the entire range of your "ant trail" resulting in a huge amount of map control (barely anyone can sneak past a large ant trail and if the trail is attacked at one point the battle will quickly escalate due more and more ants quickly accumulating at the conflict site).

As to be expected in every early access game the units themselves have some balancing issues (upgrading brood tiles just isn't worth it as more ants are always better and the Formica rufa shooters are ridiculously overpowered) but none of these actually detract from the gameplay or the fun, so they don't matter in the end.

Right now the game has 2 formicarium challenges (with your genetically modified Formica ereptor ant), 4 missions (2 with Formica fusca and 2 with Formica rufa) and the 4 old demo levels (with a Formica ereptor/fusca hybrid colony). If you play them all (including the old demo levels) that should keep you busy for about 10-20 hours (depending on how well you do).
It seems a fair price to me, especially when considering that the final product will be much more and have features like a freeplay mode, more missions and more ant species (obviously) and a campaign.

The developers have been working on this game for years so it is unlikely that this project will be abandoned. The team is small though (3 programmers and a community manager), but they're working really hard and development speed should increase once all major bugs (especially those related the unit navigation aka units getting stuck which still sometimes happens around the entrance areas and cliffs) are squashed - the game has made amazing progression in that regard during the closed beta test so I'm confident this soon will be an issue of the past.




TL'DR:

This game is lots of fun and has a vast potential to become an AMAZING game. It is not your average RTS game and that's good. Obviously it is still in early access and doesn't have tons of content but the content it has is good and makes you want more. I can wholeheartedly recommend it but if you think it's not worth buying yet just put it on your "followed games" list and keep an eye out for future updates.


(p.s. I got the game for free but I am not affiliated with the developers in any way. In fact I was gifted it due to my feedback posts on the game's official forums so I could take part in the closed beta test and give further feedback as I wasn't able to back/buy the game at that time due to technical issues.)

38777968.review:
I first saw EotU at a convention a year or two ago and instantly knew it was a game I never knew I'd always wanted. Maybe that doesn't make sense, but it's the only way I can think to describe it - a seemingly very niche appeal yet the whole group of friends I was with were intrigued by this new, innovative entry to the minion-management/base-builder RTS genre. Is there a succinct name for it? MMBBRTS is a bit of a mouthful...

Flash forward to now and I'm delighted with this game. It's great fun, it's challenging and it has a unique charm. I feel like I'm doing Slug Disco's creativity a disservice by comparing EotU to the Dungeon Keeper games but both EotU and DK stand out as groundbreaking games in the MMBBRTS genre. SimAnt is possibly another entry worth mentioning here but, as I never played it (BOO SHAME SHAME), I can't really give any meaningful commentary.

The gameplay, as I said before, is quite challenging. The initial tutorial seems overwhelming at first but once you start messing about you'll soon get a hang of how things work. Be prepared to restart your Formicarium due to poor strategy - I got my head kicked in by the first challenge mission for the Formicarium because I'd built a colony entirely of worker ants. I didn't realise I had to unlock the soldiers in the tech tree! Derp. Ended up having to restart my campaign to fix the formicarium.
The graphics are way beyond what I expected. They certainly don't [i]need[/i] to be realistic for this type of game and yet I'm so glad they are. I find my skin crawling whenever I tunnel into a spider's lair or accidentally unleash a horde of devil's coach horse bugs. UGHHHH!
My only gripe with the game is, as mentioned earlier, if you build your Formicarium poorly to begin with you'll have to restart your campaign if you want to reset it. Not the end of the world but a bit annoying, especially as my impatience made me restart the first level several times after my base got wiped out by the big boys.

In an era of shitty, broken early-access games, Empires of the Undergrowth stands out as a shining gem, crafted by a company with a genuine love for their game coupled with the talent to make it work. I can't wait to see what the future will bring, both for this game specifically and for Slug Disco as a company.

Pros:
Great concept
Great gameplay (so far)
V Good graphics
Interesting campaign - the mixture of the longplay Formicarium with the standalone missions works nicely so far.

Cons:
Very few, mostly things that I feel will get ironed out in future releases.
Tutorial is a bit confusing and initially feels overwhelming
No subtitles
Can't reset Formicarium without starting new campaign

38685795.review:
[i]Review written for version 0.11421 Early Access[/i]


[h1][i]TL;DR[/i][/h1]


If you like Dungeon Keeper and RTS games, this game will be right up your alley. It's a little light on content, but it shows promise and has a nice polish to it. It doesn't do an amazing job of explaining the controls and mechanics, but you pick it up pretty easily if you're familiar with how an RTS plays. I'm excited for more of this game. Highly recommended.


[h1]Pros[/h1]


[list]
[*]Great RTS mechanics
[*]Wonderful soundtrack and voice acting
[*]Performance is good, even with large on screen battles
[*]Unique gameplay mechanics work well for it
[/list]




[h1]Cons[/h1]


[list]
[*]Game can be confusing at start and you are immediately thrown into the game with no real tutorial aside from blocks of text
[*]Not much content (obvious for an early access title)
[/list]




[h1]Summary[/h1]


Empires of the Undergrowth is a RTS/Tower Defense-esque game with hints of Dungeon Keeper. I honestly had a hard time finding something I didn't like about this game. It doesn't have the most intuitive UI or controls but they're fairly easy to pick up. The game doesn't really have a proper tutorial. It kind of throws you into your first level alongside a barrage of tooltips and hints that tell you how to play the game. Nevertheless, once you learn to play, it's really not any harder to pick up any other RTS. However, Empires of the Undergrowth has two mechanics that help it stand out.


First of all, are the two 'layers' of gameplay. You have your nest, where the level must be carved out like a Dungeon Keeper style game, and then the surface which plays more like your typical RTS. This gives the game a very interesting mechanic as later maps reveal a day and night cycle which brings out strong creeps at night giving the opportunity for adventurous players to explore or protect their own assets (such as aphid fields) or lets cautious ones retreat to the safety of their nest.


The Formicarium is another unique mechanic. It gives the player a sort of 'home base' so to speak. I thought at first it was some kind of hub world but the Formicarium is more like your home base. You can do levels where you act out scenarios as other ant colonies. By doing these, you unlock food, upgrade points, and expansion points for your base. The Formicarium also has challenges, which function as a kind of wave survival. You can also upgrade your ants at your base and unlock new units. After completing the early access content, you are given control of the wave spawner, allowing you to swarm yourself with enemies. This were fun but it seemed that you were able to survive extremely large amounts of enemies by just retreating to your nest, using its entrance as a chokepoint.


The game is also fairly polished and it runs well. It probably won't win any beauty competitions but it certainly isn't the ugliest thing. The music also stood out to me. It seemed very fitting and was really well done. The voice acting, while not phenomenal, is more than adequate. There are 3 VAs in the game, a male scientist, a female scientist, and a narrator. The narrator and female scientist are very subdued and appropriate sounding for the game, while the male scientist has kind of this 'anime villian' kind of voice. It isn't bad, but it could probably be dialed back a bit.


Either way, Empires of the Undergrowth stuck out to me. It's an early access game so there isn't a lot of content, but the content it does show has a LOT of potential. I was pleasantly surprised when I picked this up. This game shows promise and I can't fault it for being a little slim on content as an early access game. The content that IS there shows a hell of a lot of promise and I think it does a great job at providing a varied experience of the game.

38644408.review:
估计很多人和我一样，怀着儿时的梦想：弄一个透明玻璃蚂蚁窝，像法布尔那样兴致盎然地盯着蚁后怎么一步步扩张她小小的王国。
首先关于这游戏的操作，其实很简单。模拟的是费洛蒙标记，也就是你只能给目标地点设置集结点，属于当前分组（下面会详细解释）的蚂蚁就会本能地往那边聚集。但它们不会像训练有素的士兵那样停在原地，而是在这个区域附近乱转看有什么可做的工作。
一开始屏幕下方靠右的是建造菜单，分为巢穴功能和蚂蚁孵育室。巢穴功能里有餐具样图标的是食物储备区，造一个5食物，还有行动加速区。蚂蚁孵育目前有三种，一种是工蚁，一种是近战的兵蚁，一种是喷蚁酸的兵蚁（需要解锁）。通过在基因增强界面购买升级，蚂蚁能够和建筑一样升至三级。这个很重要，而且蚂蚁在购买了类似脱战回血，加20%攻速这样的增强后会比原先强大很多。
建筑的升级需要消耗和建造同样的资源。但效果也立竿见影，蚂蚁孵育区的升级可以直接把这个区孵化的那只蚂蚁升级，血量和攻击都会提升。很多时候选择升级而不是堆更多蚂蚁效果更好。（特别是主线一开始只有50蚂蚁上限，而无德研究员放下来的喷酸aoe外加群体混乱的大虫子，“蠼螋”，可以迅速秒掉你成片的近战兵蚁，故升级是绝对必须的）建筑修建成片相连会让建筑更快达到可升级的要求，但同一片区孵化的蚂蚁会被强制归为一组，无法分开，指挥也只能统一，所以兵蚁比较适合这么做。工蚁可以适当分几个小片。屏幕下方的分组框里，最左边的是无法指挥的巢穴巡逻。你没有设置其他分组的蚂蚁会被归到里面。这里的蚂蚁会自动在巢穴范围里找活干。除了单独派去挖特定区域土的工蚁可以全放在这里。兵蚁除了不能挖土和搬卵，工蚁能干的都能干。选中当前分组（点组的编号）再点目标就能设置集结点，集结点上的数字是目前已经前往该地点的蚂蚁。

38383850.review:
This is already a very fun game, and with further upgrades it could be awesome. It captures the 'feel' of being an ant queen, with some interesting strategic concepts unique to this game. It lacks the strategic depth of something like Starcraft, but given the subject material that's not surprising. 

One significant innovation is that the construction of buildings requires a rather high cost and support only a single ant each--but replacing an ant is automatic and cheap (but not free). This means that constructing a large army is hard, but if a large army is lost it can be replaced quickly. This leads to an interesting debate, about whether it's better to keep a 'reserve' of resources in case you suffer casualties, or spend it on increasing your army size. 

Now for the complaints:
1) There's no real pop cap in the side missions, only limited by the number of buildings you currently have. But there is a pop cap in the 'home base'. This seems unnecessary, and limits your options when you need to defend it. 
2) There's a big difference in difficultly between the side missions and the 'challenge' (i.e. home base) missions--the latter are much tougher. The idea is you can play the side missions multiple times, to build up your forces at your home base. The problem is that this forces you to play the same missions over and over, no variety, which gets annoying after a while. 
3) The game right now is really just tower defence--defend against waves of enemies. It would be much better to include multiple ant colonies, each one attacking and defending. How cool would it be to send in an ant commando force to assassinate another queen? 

I recommend supporting this game now, because it's already worth the money. And it could be incredible in the future.

There's also quite a bit to be done in the ant farm section of the game which provides a different sort of challenge than the separate maps. 
I'm hoping that they add a bit more to combat in future updates because it's mostly focused on having the number advantage at the moment. Full preview can be read [url=https://oldgrizzledgamers.com/first-glimpse/empires-of-the-undergrowth-pc-review/] here [/url]. 38378491.review:
Very entertaining. While the game is/was in early access during this review, my feeling is it's already good and it will get even better for the full release, so I recommend it. The visuals, music and voiced narration gives the game a BBC documentary feel to it. The main campaign is set in a laboratory where scientists are testing your capabilities as a colony, additional "side quest" scenarios will let you grind up some resources for your brood to prepare for the tests.

You control the ants using pheromone markers, they can be grouped and each group controlled separately. You control the flow of ants for a macro strategic advantage rather than squad based tactics or micro managing single units. It's all about getting into that swarm mentality, all or nothing battles where overwhelming the enemy is the only option. Single ants are useless, but the swarm can clear the entire area of all living things in minutes.
As such, timing the resource spending and marker positions is crucial for success. Overspend or misplace a marker at the wrong time and your colony might not be able to recover.

While the game is a bit short on content at this time, it is very much playable, stable and fun. All the core mechanics and controls are solid and given time more content will be added. More game modes will also be added in the future, I'm guessing there will be something like sandbox, capture and hold, etc. If they add multiplayer this would be my new favourite strategy game.

While the Linux port had some issues early on, the devs have already patched that and with my 15 hours of gameplay in Linux I have not run into any technical issues.

38329922.review:
So far so great! I will keep this updated as new versions of EotU are released.


I was a Kickstarter backer from 2015, and I'm thrilled with the current state of the game. A lifelong ant-lover and strategy gamer, I had been craving a new SimAnt for decades. Anyway, here's the current breakdown of the game:


+ cool overworld/hub setup; beating individual scenarios yields upgrade resources for the main colony
+ three current unit castes (with sub-specializations): worker, melee, ranged. More are coming!
+ fun 'Dungeon-keeper'-esque base-building macro
+ streamlined resource management (no upkeep costs/starvation, though if you're out of food during a battle, you've probably already lost)
+ clever, squad-based micro system

+/- current number of levels and reward quantities implies you'll be replaying levels, though you can do harder difficulty levels to keep things interesting

- animations are still clunky
- unit models and/or UI icons need more distinctions between them. That's tricky, because you still want the colony to look biologically like one species, but I really can't tell what castes I'm looking at when playing as Wood Ants or Black Ants

The jury is really still out on this.  What's there is very stable, as good of graphics as you'd expect from a finished game, but there's still quite a bit of work to be done on the content side.  There's some interesting scenarios that show you what the game can offer... rushing to grab snacks off a beach before the tide rolls in and night comes, bringing lair raiding wolf spiders... but there's really only four scenarios like this for now.

For now you basically have tank units, and ranged units, or different variations of the two.  The workers ants are there just to help collect food and nest maintenance.  These are ants, of course, so there probably will never be a unit that melts your enemies face and clones his body.  This isn't Total Annihalation...  

The graphics are great though, and you really get the feeling that you're on the business end of running this colony.  I hope they figure out a way to add some more depth to the strategy side of the game, without making face melting ants.

Job well done so far.  Is it worth $20 USD?  Perhaps not in its current state, but if it continues along these lines and given enough time, I'd say probably.  It's not Rimworld with ants.  Not yet.

38255547.review:
Kritik und Lob,

eine positive Bewertung, da ein schönes Spiel, 
passt jedoch bitte den Preis dem bisherigen Content an.
Wenn mehr kommt, ist der Preis gerechtfertigt,
aber für gefühlte 6h Missionen ist das zu viel.
(Ist ja auch angekündigt, aber bis dahin kann man halt nur 10 Euro verlangen ^^ )

--------------------------------Early Bird----------------------------------

Ein Problem was mich allgemein stört heutzutage,
der Early-Bird-Markt wird grenzenlos ausgenutzt um massig Geld für
unzureichende Arbeit zu verlangen, gedeckt unter dem Begriff Early Bird.
Entweder man hat zumindest schon was auf die Beine gestellt mit dem sich arbeiten lässt,
um aber dann mit Low-Budget-Preisen und der Community das Ding rund zu feilen,
oder es ist halt zu dem Zeitpunkt nicht für die Öffentlichkeit bestimmt.
Heutige Earlie's gehen oftmals nicht weit weg vom Preis fertiger Spiele,
was aus meiner Sicht dann kein Early-Bird mehr ist.
Die Geschichte war anfangs dazu da, um Entwicklern einen leichteren Start und mehr Möglichkeiten aufgrund kleiner Einkommen zu ermöglichen, wiederrum aber auch das Spiel für nur einen BRUCHTEIL des geplanten späteren Wertes zu verkaufen, aber wenn ein Spiel mit 29,99 Euro an den Start geht als Early, dann ist das doch schon weit davon weg,
egal welcher Titel.

Da sollte es eine durch Steam gesteuertes Preislimit geben,
mit einem max. Betrag von 10 Euro, vllt. 15 Euro. 
Das reicht bei weitem für einem Titel,
denn man als unfertig vermarktet und so werden Publisher genötigt, ihre Arbeit fortzusetzen,
statt nur den Klingelbeutel aller paar Tage zu wechseln.
Ich sag nur, vor 10-15 Jahren wären kein Publisher auf die Idee gekommen, seinen Haufen unfunktionierenden Datenmüll auch noch für Geld zu verkaufen,
und trotzdem gingen grandiose Titel an den Start und auch schon damals wurde im Rahmen des Möglichen die Community einbezogen.
Nun könnte man sagen, wer nicht kaufen will der muss ja nicht, 
aber bitte bedenkt, das nicht nur Leute auf Steam wandeln,
welche sich dem bewusst sind, sondern auch Kinder und sonstige Game-Suchtie's,
welche unrational einfach nur das Zeug in den Warenkorb stecken weil es auf den ersten Blick "gut aussieht".

An Steam: Bitte führt noch eine Spalte für seperate Early-Bird Bewertungen ein,
in welcher man Preis und Leistung für den aktuellen Status ersehen kann,
z.B. aktuallisiert aller 2 Wochen, so bekommen Nutzer ein recht aktuelles Feedback der Community zum derzeitigen Stand der Dinge.
Klar gibt es bereits Reviews, aber sein wir ehrlich, 
je nach kostenpunkt der Geschichte ließt sich doch kein Mensch 1000 Reviews auf 5 Sprachen durch,
hier benötigen wir das Stern-Bewertungs-System eine Abgrenzung in: 
-Perfomance
-Preis
-Communityzusammenarbeit/Support
-Update- und Patchfrequenz
-Anzeige der geplanten Early-Bird-Dauer

----------------------Empires of the Undergrowth--------------------

Jetzt zurück zum Spiel an sich..
Schön strukturiert und liebevolle Umgebung.
Warum das mit den weiteren Maps solange dauert, ist mir nicht ganz klar,
da sich bei der Art und Weise der Mapstruktur, 
(nicht herablassend, sondern rein objektiv betrachtet)
eine derartige Karte wahrscheinlich in 1 1/2 mit zugehöriger Mission erstellen lässt,
wobei die Überlegung zu den Missionsaufgaben dabei wahrscheinlich den größten Zeitanspruch hat, wenn man davon ausgeht, das der Grundstein schon gelegt wurde.
(Hier die Überlegung mehr mit der Community zu arbeiten, die brennen darauf.. )
wahrscheinlich werden aber erstmal wichtigere Dinge wie Performance usw.  gepatcht,
den gearbeitet wird dran, Patches kommen so aller 2 Wochen,
es ist also keine Early-Bird-Leiche.

Sonst kann man sagen, ist schon mal was anderes,
als seine "Mittelalter-" oder "Neuzeitarmee" in den Kampf zu schicken.
Dabei wechselt Ihr zwichen eurem Formicarium, ich nenne es mal (1.)Homebase,
welche Ihr durch (2.)Nebenmissionen und dort erhältlichen Loot erweitern könnt.


Wenn Ihr die ersten beiden Sub-Missionen gespielt habt, 
dann könnt Ihr auch in der Homebase eine Invasion starten lassen, 
stets geleitet durch eure beiden wahnsinnigen Forscher, 
welche hier und da mal nen guten Tipp aus dem "Hintergrund" geben,
wenn diese nicht gerade Todesschwadrone aus Ameisen, Grillen und Spinnen sowie sämtliches anderes Geschmeiß in euer Heim werfen, um die Widerstandskraft der Kolonie zu prüfen.

Alles in allem sehr cool und ich bin gespannt was noch so an Content folgt,
den das Spiel mit seiner Idee ist Klasse, macht weiter so.. 

und wenn ihr einen Übersetzer benötigt, sagt Bescheid,
bisher ist das Spiel komplett auf englisch, also Fremdsprachkrüppel aufgepasst,
sonst werdet Ihr wohl wenig Freude haben wenn Ihr außer yes und no nicht viel versteht,
auch wenn vieles intuitiv machbar ist ^^

PS: Tipp an alle, die sich wundern, warum keine Nahrung erstellt wird nach Abschluss der Sub-Missionen:
Ihr müsst an die Oberfläche. Also diesen runden Button oben am Ende des Formicariums mal mit einer "Bau"-Ameise besuchen, freigraben und dann kann es losgehen. Die Oberfläche wählt ihr über die 2. Minimap an, welche nach Eröffnung des Tunnels aktiv wird. Dort findet Ihr dann die Nahrungsberge, welche Ihr vorher so schmerzlich vermisst habt. 
Grund hinter der Logik.. Euer Formicarium wird ja von den "Forscher" am Leben erhalten und die schmeißen  die Nahrung natürlich auf die Oberfläche und reißen nicht das ganze Ding ein, um ne Beere in eure Nahrungskammer zu schieben ;D
Nur so lässt sich die 1. Challenge bewältigen, sonst probiert ihr mit euren bestenfalls 5-10 Ameisen eine Invasion abzuhalten, die etappenweise von erst 10 auf 100 Ameisen ansteigt und sich selbst mit perfekt entwickeltem Tech-Baum nicht stoppen lässt.

Grüße aus der Unterwelt ^^

38246705.review:
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There are two sections to the gameplay, the first being in the form of missions, in which you build and advance forward, whilst upgrading your ant nest spreading out across an enclosed map until you complete each given mission objective which normally is domination.

The second aspect is in the formicarium (test lab) in which you build your nest, working your way through a sorta of basic tech tree using the rewards from the above missions. battles in this mode are conducted by the scientist unleashing a X-amount of enemy bugs into your cage.

[h1]General Comments[/h1]

The overall game is quite hard, on anything but the more easier levels, and experience is the key with this game. So start of with easy is my personal suggestion. it can be rather too boring on easy, but not half as frustrating as the higher levels.

Because how the levels and upgrades work you are going to be repeating the same levels many many times if you wish to max out that tech-tree, This can make the game slightly boring in some regards.

Development offers something very different, with a kind of wildlife documentary, style commentary overlaided on the action combined with the chatter of scientists make the games atmosphere something pretty unique.

Due to its Early Access status, the length of the game is pretty short in terms of levels, but there is plenty of scope with the ability to perform challenges, repeat levels, and as mention playing on hard will return hours of trying. and in my experience zero bugs present

... besides the insects!!

Geforce 960 GTX
16GB DDR3 Ram

1920x1080 @ 60+fps (max graphics)

[h1]Score[/h1] 9/10

38245073.review:
This game is brilliant fun, and has vast amounts of potential. 

The game is split into two elements, firstly the formicarium (ant farm) is where you expand your colony and improve, to the sound of the voice acted dialogue of a pair of scientists who are studying you, one of which is apparently extremely perverse and loves to see you suffer. In this mode you are able to improve the genetics of your ants by spending "royal jelly" and so choose their strengths and weaknesses and when you're powerful enough you can participate in formicarium challenges, the completion of which will result in some extra food, territory points (needed for digging within the formicarium) and some royal jelly. The issue is that food is fairly sparse in the formicarium and so in order to make reasonable progress, you need to play the missions. 

Different missions are available depending on the level of your formicarium, at first two missions are available. After improving the formicarium to level 2 by completing the challenge, you will be able to participate in the next two levels. At the moment only 4 missions are available, but with 4 difficulty settings as well as an added "challenge mode" (which adds a twist to the level you are playing) there should be enough to keep you busy for now. Each of these missions is narrated beautifully in a way which wouldn't be out of place in a nature documentary. 

In addition to this, there are an additional 4 "Alpha game modes" accessed from the extra modes section of the main menu, and there will be a custom and freeplay mode in the main game, 

Due to the excellent narration I actually found this game very educational and I came away from playing it knowing a lot more about ants and their preditors than when I went in bare in mind however that some artistic license has been taken with some species in order to provide better gameplay. 

Finally, the in game music is brilliant, a brass orchestral track really sets the tone and the music changes somewhat dynamically with the in game action.

I bought this game knowing that it's still under development, I was aware that the amount of content was somewhat limited but this game archs back to a time when RTS games where innovative. This is the first truly innovative RTS game I've played in years and I really can't wait for the future of this game.

Fuck these game creators for making level 1 ridiculously hard without any warning to the player or ability to create user saves.  This is bad design.  

Basically, you use the mini-levels to prepare for a superlevel that is similar to a tower-defense, rather than using this cumulative level to teach the player how to progress, it punishes the player via an irreversible auto save (read: iron man) mode, so there is no room for making a mistake.

I built two armies, but apparently did not save up enough food, so after retrying the level 1 formicularium about 7 times I am giving up.  FWIW I love hard games, but this is one of those games you have to fail hardcore and restart, doing the same mundane tasks for hours because there's no way to undo any mistakes you might have made as a new player.

This kind of shit went out in the 1980s as a strategy for arcade gamers to pump more quarters.  Why is this in a computer game in 2017?

38238378.review:
[h1]Empires of the Undergrowth - это симулятор муравьиной колонии, который способен всего после нескольких часов игры заставить человека абсолютно равнодушного к муравьям отправиться в гугл, на ютуб и в дедовскую энциклопедию, чтобы узнать про них побольше. [/h1]

Полный обзор: http://blast-games.ru/obzori/empires-of-the-undergrowth-obzor/

Несмотря на то, что Empires of the Undergrowth совсем недавно вышла в ранний доступ, она уже сейчас способна развлечь, лишена в принципе каких бы то ни было багов и контента вам хватит часов на 6-8 игры, как минимум. Мне игра определенно понравилась и для этого есть несколько довольно веских причин. Во-первых, это первая игра с 1991 года, а именно тогда вышла SimAnt, которая позволяет порулить муравьиной колонией. Но это, конечно, не самое главное – самое главное то, что играть в Empires of the Undergrowth весело, интересно и даже познавательно.

Геймплей не приедается, а сама игра не превращается в рутину, потому что вы не проходите одну миссию за другой просто чтобы пройти – вы делаете это, держа в голове вполне четкую цель (прямо, как муравей) — нужно собрать ресурсы, вернуться с ними в свою колонию и продолжить ее развивать.

Наличие челленджей и древа технологий также добавляет разнообразия игровому процессу. Я с нетерпением жду того, что получится у Slug Disco Studios в итоге, но уже сейчас могу сказать, что почти наверняка это будет очень хорошая игра.

38229299.review:
EotU is a very charming game. The narrator is written to sound like a nature documentary, the ants, bugs, and other critters are real critters and look very much like their real life counterparts. The overall graphics, art, and level design is absolutely lovely.

Gameplay: EotU plays like many other RTS and colony management games that came before it. Economy management, balancing unit ratios, and sending units to the most strategically advantageous positions at the right time. That's not a bad thing, because it does those things pretty well. I agree with some of the other reviews, in that unit costs, damage and other stuff could use some balancing. But as this game only released a few days ago and is still in development, that's forgivable in my opinion.

Overall, this game is a very fun game. I can clearly tell that the developers put a lot of love into this game, and truly care about it. I am excited to watch this game grow in the coming months.

38211054.review:
Great game, I highly recommend. Concept is very innovative, but you already know that. 
Graphics are clean, game is fluid, and it's is kind of realistic in the making. It's not just a classic RTS with units replaced by ants and others insects but there is a very immersive gameplay. Ants have their own consciousness, everyone of them know what they have to do and you can't control them neither select them. You control the expansion of the nest, create chambers and groups, and place pheromones on the map to lead the expansion. But there is an eratic behavior of the units you cannot really control or lead with exactness. For exemple, if you place pheromones at the other side of the map, an ant who try to reach it will grab the first food it see and go back to bring it to the nest because well, it's an ant, and the most important thing is to pile up food and defend the queen. However, you can order ants to not fight or not pick up food. In the same way you can create variant sort of ants : workers, fighters, fighter that spit (no sexual joke). In some missions you'll have to make mixed group like workers escorted by fighters. 
Difficulty is well balanced. Not to easy to make it boring, not to hard to make you stop. 
At the moment I'm writing this evaluation, this game lack a bit of content but it came out last week and there is just the few firsts missions of the story mode that made me play 17 hours. 
I didn't have so much fun on a video game for a long time. 
++ 11/10 would love to defend the queen from cockroach and recycle spiders to make food again.

38158538.review:
Ich gebe dem Spiel mal eine positive Bewertung, auch wenn es zur Zeit noch keine 20 Euro wert ist - einfach das Setup hat das schon verdient.

Zum Spiel selbst:
Man hat eine Ameisenkolonie, die man ausbauen muss. Die dafür benötigten Ressourcen gewinnt man durch Missionen, in denen man eine eigene Kolonie spielen muss und es mit diversen Insekten aufnehmen muss. Dabei ist man immer auf der Jagd nach zusätzlicher Nahrung, denn nur so kann man seine Kolonie vergrößern und mehr und stärke Ameisen aufstellen - und dieser Kampf um Nahrung ist wirklich hart, spätestens ab der 3. Mission muss man genau abwägen, ob die zusätzliche Nahrung die potentiellen Verluste an Truppen ausgleichen können oder nicht.

Es gibt auch einen Techtree, mit dem man die Ameisen verbessern kann, der steht aber nur in der Hauptkolonie zur Verfügung. Diese lebt normalerweise friedlich, aber jede 3. Mission testen Wissenschaftler die Überlebensfähigkeit und so kommt es auch hier zum Kampf.

Das Spiel läuft stabil, keine Abstürze, einmal einen Bug, der mit dem Neustart der Mission beseitigt wurde.

Aktuell gibt es leider nur 4 Missionen, die man normal oder als Challenge spielen kann, wobei letztere nur ein paar zusätzliche Gegner bringt. Zusätzlich gibt es noch 2 (?) Testmissionen gegen die Wissenschaftler. Das Spiel ist übrigens ziemlich schwer, speziell die Missionen 3 und 4 haben es in sich, wo man es teilweise mit Gegner zu tun hat, die man praktisch nicht besiegen kann - denen auszuweichen ist keine leichte Sache und man muss wirklich aufpassen, ob sich das Risiko lohnt.

Insgesamt bin ich durchaus zufrieden, auch wenn der Spielumfang momentan noch recht gering ist.

38100607.review:
Empires of the Undergrowth is currently an alpa game where you control an ant nest. At the moment the game is limited with 4 possible missions, and two challenges. The two challenges. You basically get a formicarium where you control a small nest that is limited in how much you can change it, and the food available (it even comes with a tech tree). 

You unlock more food, upgrades as well as how much of the nest can be dugout by completing the missions you get two missions that basically teach the basic game mechanics. After completing a mission you'll return to the formicarium with some royal jelly (used to unlock two types of ants and improved ant abilities). When you're feeling confident in your ant abilities you're able to launch your first challenge which will put your formicarium through several trials. If you manage to complete the challenge you'll unlock two more missions and a second challenge. 

Control of the ants is not entirely direct. Instead you can assign groups of ants (1 to 5) which are then directed to patrol from your queen to a pheromone marker. That can present some issues in that there may be occasions when your ants might walk in to a fight one by ones but as long as you're aware of what is happening this is generally easy to manage.

While I recommend the game as I personally enjoyed the challenge and narrative of the game, it should be noted the game is short as it currently is with not a lot of replayability. I am personally looking forward to seeing the game more fleshed out!

38087718.review:
Wow, watched a video on this and thought "Hey, this looks like Sim Ant meets Dungeon Keeper, I should try it out!"

I was not disappointed.

It's still early access and I'm sure plenty more missions, and more "tech tree" to be implemented but the foundation is really quite solid and challenging. I'm at a point where I'm just not interested in the big studios that much any more. Most of them are churning out sequal after sequal of the same old thing over and over again and then adding loot crates and RMT to them to milk people of every cent they have. I'd much rather give my money to a game developer that wants to create a fun, solid game, and is willing to take risks mixing up old formulas to create something fresh.

EotU is just such a game. Take some old concenpts, change them up a bit, create interesting scenarios, and let people enjoy. Well worth every penny for this early access game already, and I'll be enjoying it much more as development continues.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I've got an ant colony to guide to success...

Die Ameisen sind in einem Schaukasten bei einer Frau und Mann Zuhause, dabei stellt der Mann einem immer wieder vor Herausforderungen (wo di eFrau besser nicht erfährt), was sehr zur Story beiträgt. Deutsch vertont, was ein grosser Pluspunkt ist!

Es macht echt Spass die kleinen Ameisen zu kommandieren. Man Upgraded die Ameisen nach und nach und bekommt bei jedem neuen Raum/Ameise wieder Kommentare und Freude der "Menschen" zu hören. Besser geht ein Tutorial nicht, da es keines ist.

Die Herausforderungen sind genial, die Zwischenmissionen irgendwann mühsam, damit man genügend Nahrung zusammen hat, leider aktuell noch keine generierten Levels, was ich toll fände (Abwechslung), sonst aber ein Daumen hoch und klare Kaufempfehlung.

38085619.review:
Increíble simulador de estrategia donde controlaremos una colonia de Hormigas y tendremos que proteger la Hormiga Reina.

Os dejo mi vídeo Análisis: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8J6-a6gxc2k

El juego salios el 1/12/17 y en cuanto estuvo en Steam contacte con los desarrolladores y conseguí que me dieran una clave para mi canal.

El juego me llamo mucho la atención desde que supe de su desarrollo y me pareció una idea fresca y diferentes.

El juego tiene un enfoque didáctico y una voz en off que nos ira narrando lo que sucede en nuestras partidas de forma magistral, al más puro estilo documental del National Geographic. Lamentablemente el juego solo esta en Ingles.

Este es el único inconveniente que le veo al juego, el no tener voces en nuestro idioma o al menos subtítulos. Pero tras escuchar la voz en off en ingles, me quedaron las ganas de escuchar esa voz en nuestro idioma, que me sumerja en mi propio documental de Hormigas.

Deberemos proteger a la hormiga reina, controlando una colonia de hormigas, haciendo crecer su población y ampliando sus dominios.
 
Tendremos que escavar los túneles de nuestro hormiguero, almacenar comida suficiente para mantener nuestra poblacional, colocar las zonas donde incubar los huevos de nuestras hormigas, diciendo cuantas obreras y guerreras queremos.

Mientras vamos creando nuestro túneles nos encontraremos con otros insectos pacíficos y otros agresivos. Deberemos de eliminarlos para añadir sus restos a nuestras reservas de comida y evitar que nos maten a nuestra Hormiga Reina.

El juego esta en Acceso Anticipado por lo que su desarrollo aun esta en proceso, aun y así encontramos 2 modos de juego, uno de ellos con objetivos diferentes a completar y otro en el que tendremos nuestro propio hormiguero y según vayamos haciendo misiones iremos ganando materiales para poder ampliarlo y hacerlo crecer (os muestro este modo en el vídeo).

También podremos mejorar las estadísticas de nuestras hormigas Obreras, Guerreas y Reina. Espero que vayan desarrollando mejoras y añadan más opciones de construcción, más tipo de hormigas y por supuesto nuestro idioma.


El juego a superado con creces mis buenas expectativas y lo recomiendo a todos los amantes de los juegos de estrategia y simuladores. Encima tiene un precio bastante interesante (19,99€), si encontráis alguna rebaja mejor aun.

Juego diferente que nos pondrá en la piel de una colonia de hormigas. 

Quien no ha querido ser alguna vez una pequeña hormiga trabajadora y Feroz?

38077898.review:
Once you get past the "wow, I'm controlling ants!" part (which a lot of people fail to do, it seems), it's pretty easy to see why I'm leaving a thumbs down and getting a refund.
Game tries so hard not to be like other RTSs that it gets rid of things that actually make RTSs fun, balanced, and exciting, and ends up just being a clunky mess.

To expand upon this as people have been asking, basically instead of being able to command your units effectively, you just give them a general area to go to, some will go there and some will not. The ones that DO go there will often wander around the nest after a few seconds, then make their way back. The enemy units are, however, extremely coordinated and will go directly to your queen with no hesitation. This means any real fight is just you desperately trying to get your units to behave as the enemy steamrolls throughout your nest. The developers have claimed this is "realistic" ant behavior, but anyone who has observed ants in the wild knows that ant colonies will swarm around predators very effectively once the threat is identified and marked.

And let me just say one of my favorite games of all time is Dwarf Fortress. I am fine with not having complete and direct control over every single one of my units. I just think there should be a "mark predator" command or something that makes your soldier ants stop wandering around and get to fighting.

Also, as you can see from the comments on this review, the community for this game is trash and likes to respond to legitimate criticism with "YOU MAD?". Christ man, it's 2017.

38075134.review:
Fasciné par les fourmis depuis que j'ai soulevé ma première pierre, je jouais au jeu Les Fourmis de Bernard Werber qui ne fonctionnait que sur Windows 2000 donc je peux vous dire qu'avec environ 15 ans d'attente je suis Hypé de ouf!

Bref le jeu est très originale, je m'explique:

-Le jeu fonctionne sur des groupes de controle mais c'est beaucoup plus intuitif/simple que faire CTRL+1 etc
-L'histoire, vous dirigez une colonie "domestiquée" dans le labo d'un scientifique ... légérement sadique xD
-Vous améliorez votre colonie en jouant des missions toutes les plus amusantes les unes que les autres afin de gagner des ressources. Des missions de farming.
-Il y a le Risk/Reward, + de difficultés = + de récompences, de plus vous aurez le choix : je veux plus de nourriture par exemple
-Un arbre technologique pour votre colonie 
-Oui ça pullule ^^ (une option pour les arachnophobes)

Le jeu est court pour l'instant (4 missions de farming - 2 épreuves du scientifique - 4 missions bonus),
mais il y aura (en théorie) 10 épreuves avec 20 missions de farming au minimum pour la campagne.
Comptez une dizaine d'heures de jeu actuellement.

Le multijoueur n'est pas encore disponible.
Les escarmouches ne sont pas diponible non plus pour l'instant.

Le français n'est pas disponible (pour l'instant?) et je ne suis pas anglophone cependant j'ai dévoré le jeu sans difficultés et j'ai parfaitement compris son fonctionnement, ne vous arrêtez pas à la barrière du language...

20€ pour 10h de jeu c'est très cher MAIS 10h de bonheur, de renouveau, rien avoir avec les jeux de stratégie
actuels et l'équipe semble être à l'écoute et je n'ai aucunes craintes sur l'avenir de ce jeu (bien que les fourmis n'interessent que peu de gens...)

(Je n'ai eu aucun, oui aucun, bug)

[Modifications prévues lors de la fin de l'accés anticipé]

Este game é simplesmente fantástico e diferente, você controla um terrário de um formigueiro que está sendo estudado por cientistas.
 
A principio você tem as formigas operárias e as guerreiras, as operárias cavam e as guerreiras, claro, batalham.
Você pode controlar ate 5 grupos de formigas, e através dos feromônio você define as tarefas daquele determinado grupo, se eles vão apenas batalhar, ou se vão ajudar a recolher os alimentos espalhados pelo formigueiro. A diverão é garantida, você enfrente aranhas, besouros, lacraias. No modo Chalange sua rainha é atacada a todo momento e é necessário um grupo de formigas próximos para defendê-la, e não pense em deixar ela desprotegida em momento algum, mesmo achando que uma escavação rumo ao inimigo será dificil. Pois, ao escavar e enfrentar uma horda de lacraias vorazes, vai spawnar besouros próximo a sua rainha e devorá-la, então a estratégia é crucial para vencer. 

Além dos modos acima que são as missoes você possui um terrário onde aprimora sua rainha e suas formigas, desbloqueando outras para juntar-se a sua "guerra" ainda não cheguei tão longe.

Recomendo o jogo a todos.

O suporte responde rápido e estão empenhados sempre a melhorar e corrigir os bugs.

The game is fun, interesting mechanics, and is slow enough that I we consider it a leisure type of game.

Early Access is always a bit of a risk, but I view it like a movie ticket. If it entertains me for a few hours, it's worth it. Empires of Undergrowth fell a little bit short on the amount of content, it takes a few hours to complete the current content, signficantly less if you're knowledgable. The few hours I did play I had fun, but if you're looking to get the most bang for your buck, you may consider waiting.

Pros
-Fun
-Easy to Understand
-Lot of room for growth

Cons
-Minimal content at the moment
-Starting instructions are a bit sparse, particularly in the formicarium
-The need to resource farming in challenge mode is neat, but maps are repetitive. They could use at least several versions of the maps or some random generation. 

Overall I still say it's a buy because this is an Early Access and I am very much looking forward to what you bring in next.

И так. Не так много часов, а мною пройдена фул игра.
Мураши до ужаса затягивают и требуют внимательности (и наличии чуть чуть мозгов). 
По первой было не понятно что качать, но худо бедно разобралась. Контэнта не так много, но его для старта игры с головой хватает. 

Из +:
* Очень грамотно поставлены уровни сложности. Если на легком игра старается всеми силами тебе помогать, то уже на среднем и сложном уровне, ты понимаешь, что без "котелка" на нужном месте, не пройти. А враги будто тролят "Ты господствуешь на карте? А как там твоя матка? Оу. Помоему её жрет паук!" (Ну собственно слитая катка из-за невнимательности). Честно слилась пару раз на харде из-за поспешных решений и невнимательности. 
* Прекрасно сделана возможность прокачки мурашей. Если опять же голова на месте, то прокачка решит почти все проблемы на изи и большую часть на среднечке. 
* Спасибо огромное за возможность ОТДЕЛЬНО от колонии проходить добавочные квесты, а так же иметь возможность повыживать под землей. Честно это оказалось не так легко (особенно когда пошли жуки и пауки).

Из -:
* Конечно еще очень мало уровней, но это пока не критично (Да и будем честны, игра вышла только 2 декабря!)
* Мало видов муравьёв (Опять же надеямся на будущие новвоведения).
* Мало карт (Да я хочу все и сразу XD Шучу)

Графика и звуки полностью удовлетворяют. Потребность в Руссификации понадобилась сугубо только в момент прокачки мурашей (что собственно заставило меня чутка напрячь переводчик). Игра стоит своих денег (можно смело брать без скидки, вы не прогодаете). Советую всем! Надеюсь на будущие войны между игроками.

38004084.review:
給中文玩家們想買這遊戲的一些評論

會點進來這遊戲的人，我想或多或少都是在魔獸爭霸或者星海爭霸裡面的遊樂場玩到『螞蟻戰爭』的類似遊戲才會對這個遊戲有所興趣，還記得那段日子放陷阱控制兵蟻，偷別人蛋的日子。

這是一款專精螞蟻的遊戲，如果你對螞蟻的生態有興趣而且喜好即時戰略的遊戲，那這款真的是不錯的選擇。

但是這款遊戲仍在開發階段，所以不免內容有些匱乏，但是你要想想，天啊這是一款專精螞蟻的RTS遊戲耶!!

400以內就能買到的價格，如果對螞蟻的生態略有研究的人就會知道，螞蟻的社會以及演化是極度有趣的。

要是未來能夠推出DLC關於新螞蟻或是多人連線之類的肯定會很棒。

我就舉些未來作者如果夠聰明會開發的東西。

『陷阱』『蟻獅』『切葉蟻』『蘑菇』『牙蟲』『氣候』『多人模式』『合作模式』

-----優點-------

1. 遊戲音樂非常的經典到位，以輕柔的音樂帶動穩定的旋律，戰鬥時則用非常嚴肅的一刻每一次的戰鬥都攸關蟲巢的生死。

2. 昆蟲昆蟲昆蟲，這很重要。我們要看的就是昆蟲打昆蟲。目前遊戲中出現的昆蟲不多，但是我的老天! 是昆蟲耶!

3. 雖說是即時戰略遊戲但是也跟經營很有相關，每一格建築物都會相互影響。『道路』若是單一一條路線則可以立刻進行升級，但是挖開變大了之後就得要用更多的道路堤滿才能升級。『蟲巢』與其它蟲巢貼近時也能獲得加成，方得升級。

4.螞蟻升級靠得是巢穴的龐大。舉例來說一格兵蟻巢需要6個+1才能升級，若旁邊圍繞成一個圈，每一格都會+1。這樣就能升級成2級兵蟻。這遊戲的攻擊與防禦力看的是1 - 3 階的巢穴所產出的螞蟻，所以沒有研究武器的項目，但是這樣也是平衡遊戲的方式。

----------缺點-------

1. 目前遊戲尚未開發完畢

2. RTS的控制其實不太妥當，沒有所謂的集中攻擊單一目標，所以常常會有一種兵多效益差的戰鬥。

3. BUG還是有，因為還在開發。『洞蜘蛛』因為BUG螞蟻不去打它結果我就被她狠狠吃了30幾隻螞蟻直接崩盤。

----總結-----

喜歡昆蟲喜歡螞蟻生態的玩家絕對不要錯過，世界上屬於螞蟻的遊戲已經很少了。把你那一點點的夢想，寄託給這家遊戲廠商吧!

注意，目前遊玩的東西仍然非常稀少，斟酌購買

37993934.review:
It's pretty obvious this game is a labor of love from some creepy people who really like ants and other bugs.

While it might take a few minutes to figure out how to get the ants doing what you want them to be doing, there's more to managing a colony than meets the eye. There are 2 basic classes of ant - the workers and the warriors. There's a queen too, but she doesn't do much - she's a liability: you have to defend her at all costs because every other ant can be replaced. If the queen dies, the colony dies.

The goals are simple and realistic: ants need food to make more ants. More ants = good. But more ants means food gets used up. No food = bad. So your main task involves getting more food for the colony and all that entails: food has to be stored. Food sometimes belongs to other critters who don't want to share. And sometimes the food just doesn't want to be eaten. Even worse, sometimes you run into things that think ants are food. How wrongheaded can you be?

While this could get boring quickly, the devs have designed the game in an interesting way: You have a basic, simple and vulnerable colony. To improve this you need to play scenarios to improve your colony by researching different ant abilities, etc, or just getting more food for your colony. You need to do this to survive the next step, which is the colony challenges. In challenges all the decisions you've taken will be tested and failure means your colony and your queen dies. Thank goodness for save games!

Hopefully as this game is developed the devs will up the ante even more or include some sort of randmization to allow replayability which is one eventual drawback that might show up in the future. However after a couple hours I still can't survive that first challenge and my colony still needs work.

This means I'm hooked for now.  I want to see what's in store further down the road, and while the game is extremely simple (it's ants, after all. They eat. They move. They die) and even grindy, I don't mind because it's the ants that do the grinding. They don't mind - it's what they do! The big picture - getting a colony that can survive what the devs throw at it - that's quite a bit harder.

Well done!

37988226.review:
Very nice strategy game. 
Although the Early Access just started, it already makes a lot of fun to play. 

In Formicarium (terrarium for ants) Mode (Story Mode) you have 4 Missions with varied targets, like "kill everything else than your own ants on the map"," survive egg stealing-ants", "deal with other ants who want to have the same resources than you", "survive nights with bug attacks", "defend honeydew giving aphids", etc...
You play a genetically modified ant species in a formicarium, observed by two macabre scientists. You will get the genes of other ant species you defeated in the missions. 
That means you can unlock other ant species when you play missions and insert these new units into your colony.
This will give you a few hours to play.

There are also a few other, old missions + a free mode where you can spawn as many food and enemies as you want.


I'm excited of new stuff, new, ant species, new biomes (until now you can only play at beach), new gameplay features...

39380508.review:
一通りプレイしメインチャレンジはクリアしたのでレビュー。
まず他の人も言うようにとにかくアリ。アリゲー。ハサミムシやクモなんかも出てくる。虫嫌いな人はそっ閉じしましょう。
字幕音声共に英語のみだがシステムやUIがシンプルなので繰り返しプレイしていれば直ぐに慣れる。
説明テキストも英語が苦手な自分でもフィーリングでなんとか。
ゲームシステム自体は非常にシンプルだが、全体的に難易度はやや高めか。OtherModeも幾つか触ってみたが少々難しめ。
EA版という事で現時点でのボリュームは非常に少なく、メインミッションは2つまでしかない(UIを見るに10くらいまで実装の予定か？)。

メインモードではこの2つのミッションをクリアすればとりあえず現時点ではクリアなのだが、難易度は相応に高くそのままでは食料やローヤルゼリーといった強化に必要なリソースは足りない。
リソースを集めるためには各レベル毎に用意された2つのサブミッションをクリアしなければならないが、初回以外は供給量が少なく、またサブミッションとはいえ時間もそこそこ掛かるのがネック。
かといって各1回クリアしただけでは苦しい為、ある程度は反復する必要がある。内容も各サブミッションの難易度毎に決まっており、変化も少なく慣れればただの作業ゲーとなってしまう。
とはいえ、サブミッション自体はメインとはまた異なった内容なのでそこそこ楽しい。難易度も選択できるので高難易度への挑戦もしがいがある。

マイナス評価になるのはこの点くらいか。ボリュームについては徐々に増えていくと思うので期待。
ゲーム全体としてはこういったシンプルなRTSやTD系ゲームが好きな自分にとってはなかなか楽しく、今後の開発によってより深く楽しめる作品になれば良いなという期待も込めて好評価に。
アップデートが待ち遠しい作品です。

ただ、仕様なのかバグなのか不明ですが、移動速度アップマス(コスト5の通路マス)はあらゆるマスに対して壁と同じようにLvアップ条件にカウントされます。
この通路マス自身もレベルアップが可能なので、上手く活用してやると非常にラクに。特にメインミッション攻略には役立つでしょう。
例えば働きアリマスをLv2のマス6つで囲んだ場合、他のパネルだと0なのですが通路マスだと+2x6で合計12となり、Lv3にする為に必要な条件を満たす事が出来ます。
これを利用して産卵部屋の卵マスを囲むように通路マスを置いたり、異なる種類のマスの境界に通路マスを設置したりすると低コストでLv3のアリを多く作り出したりも出来ますし、広すぎる部屋やうっかり掘りすぎた壁の穴埋めとして使ったり、部隊を分ける為の区切りとして使ったりと応用が効くため、覚えておいて損は無いでしょう。不具合かもしれないので修正されるかもしれませんが…。

39054292.review:
Empires of the Undergrowth ist teils Simulation teils RTS im namensgebenden Undergrowth (z.dt. Unterholz)
Als Spieler übernimmt man in einer überschaubaren Anzahl an Missionen die Kontrolle einer Ameisenkolonie, und muss dafür sorgen, dass die eigene Königin überlebt und die Kolonie immer weiter wächst.

Für alle die keinen Wall of Text lesen wollen hier das Fazit als tldr:

EotU ist meiner Meinung ein guter Early-Access Titel und ein Vorzeigebeispiel für Communitykommunikation seitens Entwickler.
Ich bin ein Fan der ersten Stunde und EotU hat mich für die faszinierende Welt der Ameisen begeistern können.
Ich empfehle diese Spiel für jeden der Dungeon Keeper mag, sich für Ameisen oder Insekten im Allgemeinen interessiert oder aber Leuten, die einfach gerne sympathische Entwickler bei ihrem Herzensprojekt unterstützen möchten.

20 € ist für den derzeitigen Inhalt ein wenig zuviel aber definitiv gerechtfertigt, da damit zum Einen den Entwicklern geholfen wird und zum Anderen noch viele Features und Inhalt kommen wird.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

Die grundlegenden Mechaniken hierbei sind recht simpel, man gräbt Gänge und Bruthöhlen (ähnlich wie Dungeon Keepers)
und investiert das gesammelte Futter in Wege, Ameisenbrutplätze oder Futterkammern.

Weiterhin kann man diese Hexagon-Felder bis auf Rang 3 aufbessern, wobei man jedoch auf das Arrangement der einzelnen Bruthöhlen achten sollte:
1. Angrenzende Felder geben Punkte in Höhe des entsprechenden Ranges, welche Vorraussetzung zum Upgraden sind.
2. Alle aneinander angrenzenden Brutfelder der gleichen Ameisenart bilden einen Schwarm. 
Diesen Schwarm kann man einem Pheromonmarker zuweisen, um die Tätigkeiten und das Ziel, wohin sich der Schwarm bewegen soll zu bestimmen. Ein Pheromonmarker ist vergleichbar mit Steuergruppe in anderen RTS (z.B. Starcraft, AoE, etc.)

Möchte man also mehrere Armeen haben, sollte man auch mehrere Höhlen graben, was Platz kostet. Möchte man hochrangige Ameisen besitzen, gilt es hexagonale Strukturen anzulegen, da so die Punkteverteilung optimal ist.

Das Ganze ist sehr intuitiv, und für mich schon nach wenigen Spielminuten greifbar gewesen, ohne irgendeine Form von Tutorial.

[b][u]Schwierigkeitsgrad:[/u][/b] EotU ist schwer. Jede Mission besitzt 4 Schwierigkeiten: Easy, Normal, Hard und Insane.
Der Entwickler selbst sagt zum Balancing, dass Easy und Normal für jeden machbar sein sollte. Hard wird so gebalanced, dass die Entwickler die ganze Missionen noch schaffen und Insane ist nochmal ein Ticken schwieriger.

Ich kann diese Einschätzung bestätigen, wobei ein Schwierigkeitsanstieg zu spüren ist. Ist die Mission 1.2 auf Hard fast kein spürbarer Unterschied zu Normal, so bekommt man in Mission 2.2 dermaßen viele gegnerische Ameisen um die Ohren gepfeffert, dass man mehrere Anläufe braucht, bis man die optimale Strategie.

Meiner Meinung sorgt das für eine gute Motivation und erhöht den Wiederspielwert einzelner Missionen, neben dem Bonus, dass man Ressourcen für seine Ameisenfarm bekommt.

[h1]Inszenierung:[/h1]

Das Setting des Spiels lehnt sich an ein Biologielabor an, welches als Hauptmenü dient. 
Von hier aus kann man zu den verschiedenen Levels der Alphaversion oder aber in das eigene Formicarium bzw.  die eigene Ameisenfarm. 

Die Ameisenfarm ist ein zentraler Teil des Spiels, da man hier missionsübergreifend mit seiner Kolonie wächst und 
von hier aus werden die Storymissionen gestartet werdeb.(zurzeit sind es 4 Missionen + 2 Formicarium Challenges) Außerdem erforscht man hier neue Eigenschaften und Ameisentypen für seine Kolonie.

Das Ganze funktioniert so, dass man für jede Mission eine gewisse Anzahl an Futter, Erforschungspunkten (Royal Jelly), und Felder zum Ausgraben bekommt, um so stetig voranzuschreiten.

In den Missionen spielt man eine davon unabhängige Ameisenkolonie, die in der Art einer Naturdokumentation von einem Offsprecher begleitet wird. Man muss gewisse Aufgaben erfüllen, wie z.B. alle Kreaturen im Untergrund besiegen oder 4 Tage gegen feindliche Ameisenkolonien zu überleben.

Dabei bekommt man einige Nebeninformationen vom Offsprecher, wie die lateinischen Namen der eigenen Ameisen und andere Insekten und deren Verhaltensweisen, was der Illusion einer Naturdoku zu Gute kommt.

Da zurzeit nur 4 solche Missionen existieren, kann man noch nicht viel zur Abwechslung sagen, jedoch versprechen die Entwickler Nachschub in Form von neuen Missionen zu liefern, die immer neue Sachen ins Spiel implementieren sollen, wie z.B. Blattschneideameisen, Regenfälle, neue feindliche Gegnertypen usw.
 
An Ideen mangelt es sicherlich nicht und jeder der sich für die Weiterentwicklung des Spiels interessiert sollte auf dem Twitch bzw. Youtube Kanal von SlugDisco vorbei schauen. Dort wird regelmäßig ein Entwicklerstream abgehalten, der Einblick in die Entwicklung von EotU gibt.

Ist die Kolonie genug gewachsen und hat man alle Missionen eines Kapitels erreicht, muss man in einer Formicarium Challenge seine Kolonie auf die Probe stellen lassen, um die nächsten Missionen spielen zu können. Diese Challenge wird als Biologieexperiment der hiesigen Wissenschaftler inszeniert, wobei einer der Wissenschaftler eine leicht sadistische Neigung hat, weswegen meistens mehr Geschmeiß auf einen zu kommt, als seine Partnerin plant.

Das sorgt für eine ganz lustige Dynamik, ist spielerisch etwas zäh, da man hier meistens nur ausharrt bis endlich alle Gegner abgefrühstückt wurden. Richtige Strategien kann man hier keine entwickeln, da meistens das Halten des Kolonieausgangs genügt. 
Genügt dies nicht, muss man eventuell einige Missionen erneut spielen, um seinen Ameisen weitere Eigenschaften zu erkaufen und die Challenge erneut ausharren.
Das kann sich aber definitiv in Zukunft ändern.

[h1] Technik [/h1]

EotU basiert auf der Unreal Engine und macht insgesamt einen soliden Eindruck. In Anbetracht der Anzahl von Entwicklern (es sind 2 und ein Designer), die dazu auch noch echt sympathisch sind, bin ich definitiv zufrieden.
Die Models wirken echt, wobei ich mir bei einigen Größenverhältnissen nicht ganz sicher bin. 
Leider sind Animationen ein wenig karg, was aber definitiv zu verschmerzen ist, da ab einer gewissen Koloniegröße
das Gewusel individuelle Animationen überdeckt.
Da wir aber eine Ameisenkolonie spielen gilt sowieso Gewusel > Individualität, denn das ist es auch, was Ameisen ausmacht, für mich zumindest.

Bugs, außer die die man steuert und die die man bekämpfen muss, sind bei mir keine aufgetreten bzw. nicht aufgefallen.
Lediglich einige fragwürdige Designentscheidungen, die aber nicht unbedingt ins negative Gewicht fallen müssen.

Z.B. die Startbrut die sich um die Königin scharrt.
Diese kann nicht verbessert werden und sie sammelt nur Nahrung, die sich in der Nähe befindet. In manchen Missionen
ist das erste Futter aber schon soweit weg, dass sie dieses nach dem Ausgraben nie sehen würden.
Man muss zwar nur diese Startbrut einem Pheromonmarker zuweisen und dann wie gewohnt Futter sammeln.
Muss es dann jedoch wieder zurück ändern, damit auch neue Stellen gebaut werden.

Das Ganze ist nicht sonderlich nervig, und kann in manchen Leveln sogar als Early Game Strategie eingesetzt werden um schnell Futter zu stacken, aber die Notwendigkeit am Levelanfang könnte manche stören.

EotU ist ein Early-Access Spiel, macht aber einen sehr guten Eindruck. Vorallem Sachen die negativ sind, bzw. stören werden auf Communitywunsch auch vom Entwickler geändert. (siehe z.B. Bevölkerungslimit im Formicarium).

Weitere Inhalte die der Entwickler verspricht, können von der Community vorgeschlagen werden (siehe Devstreams), dabei wird definitiv ein Freeplay Mode entstehen, in dem mehrerer Kolonien (zurzeit nur AI) sich gegen immer andere Bedrohung beweisen müssen. Es wird neue Ameisenarten, wie z.B. die berühmten Blattschneideameisen geben, neue Gegner wie Skorpione oder dem Cordyceps Pilz und neue Mechaniken wie Jahreszeiten oder Niederschlag geben.
 
So das wars. Hier kommt nichts mehr .^\(°{}°)/^

39016496.review:
First of all I am neither qualified nor worthy to write a decent Review on this Masterpiece in the making. Second of all bear with my poor English for me not being a native speaker. I must say due to the first point I have never written a Review on Steam and I will refrain from doing so in the Future but since I was a little Kid I was fascinated by ants and this game seems like it was just created for me. 

But for now lets cut to the chase. Everyone who has a Heart for Ants wont be dissapointed by this game.

As the Mods and Developers already stated many times Empires of the Undergrowth is an early Access with more content coming soon. As for now this game contains 4 challenging Missions in "Formicarium Mode" plus Two even more challenging Formicarium challenges which you need to pass to further advance in "Formicrium mode". And without spoiling the best about the Formicarium challenges lets just say they come with a very amusing "twist".

Atmosphere 10/10: The narration during the levels reminds of a documentary- very good Voice Acting. As for the Music: very fitting, dramatic or calm or simply catching the scenery perfectly. To be honest Ive spent quite alot of Time just Listening to the Soundtrack.

Setting (10/10 or less depending on your wish for a realistic Setting):
Let me further explain this strange rating. You manage a colony of gene stealing ants in "Formicarium mode". These Ants do hopefully not exist outside of this game for they are capable of raising other specimen as their own. 

These other Specimen in Empire of the Undergrowth so far are Formica Rufa and Formica Fusca which are real Antspecies. You play your first two Missions as Formica Fusca then you must finish the First Formicarium challenge as your Gene stealing Ant colony. After that you finish the next two Missions as Formica Rufa before you can try your Luck at the Second Formicarium challenge. So you have both some really cool "Fantasy Ants"(you can determine their coloring also) and beautifully modelled realistic Ants with the promise of more of them still coming.

Game Mechanics 10/10 (early acces):
- Moving Ants through Pheromone Markers which is a great more realistic concept than just controlling them as in most 
   other RTS Games.
- By completing the Formicarium Missions you get Ressources to Upgrade your Gene Stealing Ants
- Building Tunnels and Chambers to help your Colony to survive
- Variety on Mechanics like: a rising Tide or Ladybugs trying to diminish your Food Ressources
- Underground and " Above Ground" Missions
- Wide Variation of Enemys to your colony with still more coming soon  

Community and Developers 10/10:
- Really dedicated Mods in the Forums answering every Question in a polite and efficent Way. 
- Livestreams in which you can witness the Development and even make Suggestions
- Passionate Community of Ant Lovers who try their best to make this game even better
- Frequent Bug Fixes (I didnt encountered any so far).     

But for now it seems like I have dropped my Beetles so this Review ends here :D.

39555068.review:
It's a fun RTS game that isn't very complicated. It's satisfying to do a lot of things in this game and sadly it doesn't have more content. There is a LOT of potential to be had with most of the issues right now being a lack of content.

One unique strength this game has is how it manages its units and their spawn points. You can level up an ant to level 3, and that uses a lot of food usually. Before you upgrade though, you need to surround your ant's spawn point with walls or other playermade objects. Once it is surrounded by objects worth 6 points total, you can level it up, to get it to level up again you need 12 points.

The underground segments are done on a hexagonal plane. So, when you are placing down ants you want to make them into shapes ressembling hexagons and along walls. This is how it plays into the upgrading system. Level 1 objects and walls give one point. Level 2 objects give 2, and level 3 objects give 3. To get 6 points for an ant, surround all of its 6 sides. It works nicely and encourages you even more to not build out random large sections as you'll have less walls to aid you at the beginning of making your ant army.

Sadly it's difficulty isn't very good, motar ants shred shit down so fast it's not even funny. The "challenges" your ant colony face isn't mcuh at all either. It's still fun though, as building bases and sending your ant armies around is fun enough.

Long story short, the game is fun in its current state but it's very short. So get it if you plan on keeping up. Honestly, it's not really worth it right now, but I personally would love to support the devs more. I also have faith in them keeping up the content.

39553814.review: Det innehåll som kommit ut än så länge är fantastiskt bra. Jag hoppas att de snart får ut resten av spelet. Jag har hittills köpt sämre färdiga spel för högre priser. Inte stött på några större buggar som retar mig än heller och har då spelat igenom allt som finns i huvudkampanjen.

39539410.review:
As soon as i saw this game in my steam queue, I impulsively bought it. I thought it reminded me of playing Pikmin on my wii, and building an army of tiny vegtable people to take down strange monsters on a micro scale- I would love to do that again. 

Empires of the Undergrowth thankfully held up to my expectations. The levels are engaging, the mechanics are unique, and I felt like Olimar except in a Nature Documentary. (There is a narrator explaining every challenge you face as though it's on National Geographic, which is honestly hilarious.) The way you can command squadrons of ants to do various tasks and the system that's currently in place is unique and works fairly well, although it could use some fine tuning. Additionally, for a game in the making, the soundtrack is excellent.

As of right now you start off in a formicarium that serves both as an orignal ant colony and a hub for other missions, most of which take place in the wild. The variety of challenges and different species of ants makes every different quest feel orignal and fresh- and some are quite challenging (thankfully there's an easy difficulty to make me feel like I know what I'm doing) but very fun every time. The enviroments are different as well, for example: one level takes place on a beach, and the ant colony has an extra challenge of collecting food before the tide rises and renders those areas flooded. As you race against the incoming tide, night falls and you must retreat to your colony and defend it from strange invaders (hermit crabs, followed by nasty wolf spiders) to survive until the next morning. 

Honestly I thought every bit of what this game currently offers is worthy of playing. The only drawback is that... there isn't a lot of it. The content is currently very limited for the time being, so at its current state it might be wise to wait for more content. But the good news is the development of this game is quite active and working with the community to not only get it done, but get it done right- and I for one and happy I spent the money on this game to support its development, and can't wait for more levels to be added.

40864779.review:
As a fan of Simant, I was eager to check out this title and am thoroughly surprised. Not only is Gameplay fun and challenging..mainly cause she said, NOT to go over 30 and as soon as she left the room...he said 40... then more! LOL It also has a very neat educational aspect to it. The voices are clear, well done and fit the feel of the game.  The battle music is a nice touch.  It gives the troops something to fight to as they dispatch digger beatles, lightning fast wolf spiders and big lumbering hermit crabs.   The fight scenes are pretty cool. You know the battle is won when the enemy turns belly up and your troops start dissecting the body and taking pieces home.  I like watching the ants pick up food, it's like a tiny forktruck picking up a big load but it doesnt look mechanical, then they deliver the food to storage. 

The only issues I found with this game, so far,  is that the flow of play is a little confusing and the biggest gripe... BASIC game mechanics are revealed thru info alert icons on the side of the screen during game play! WHO thought that was a good idea? Fire THAT guy...or girl... or whatever.  Here's the skinny..
You start with a queen and a handfull of workers to grow a colony.   Once you have reached your max growth, which you will do quickly,  you must do mission objectives from the button in the upper left of the screen. There are two main missions. These main missions are set up in three parts each where you have two lower missions, then the main, harder mission above the two lower mission.  You can click any mission and play it, but it's easiest to go from bottom to top playing the two at the bottom and moving up from there.   When playing other colonies, missions, you have access to upgrades almost immediately. However... as you upgrade your own colony, you are only upgrading the upgradeability... for instance... in missions, you make shooting ants right off the bat. At home, you make the ant, then upgrade it's nursery spot to give that ant the upgraded ability. So even tho you paid for the upgrade, you will only produce basic ants until you upgrade each individual ant.  That nice little tidbit of info came as my colony was getting overun and I clicked the icon on the right side of the screen by mistake.   Game mechanics and the upgrade processes should be CLEARLY spelled out and not hidden in the fine print.  


After you play a mission, you go back your home colony with any perks that you have won. You'll get food, the ability to dig and enlarge your colony, and the ability to upgrade the ants and the queen, to a varying degree that you choose.  The switching back and forth seemed strange at first but then you realize, you build multiple colonies rather than one, with changing difficulties and abilities. I found this style of game flow a little different, but very satisfying.  It's like you leave your colony to go off and help another colony then come home with goodies.  This also gives you abilities to practice with abilities that your home colony may not have yet.

Can hardly wait to see more content!
This is one of the best early access titles I have played and I recommend it 100%

40864004.review:
One of the best games I have played in a long time.

Pros: A god game in which you are both a god and the one being lorded over. (Yourself over ants, scientist over you)
- Missions were unique
- I actually felt contempt for the villain (The researcher) sadistic bas... anyway
- Graphics on epic or high is good, anything else is weird af, just keep it high or epic
- Ants AI was actually really good
- Ants were cute, spiders were horrifying --> Thank you for the aracnophobe mode XD
- Allows for a lot of self-improvement and learning of new strategy and tricks, i feel like a lot of games lack that or are too hard. EotU balances it well
- No pause button causing stress, but not in a bad way, just requires you to get good
- Missions are well varied :D not just new enemies but new concepts

Cons:
- Did not include in-game guide to enemies or ant species --> I think that would be super cool, especially if you could edit it yourself, like a bug encyclopedia you as the player can fill in
- Playing on graphic settings below high is a truely bizarre experience, like the screen is fuzzy, not blurry but fuzzy
- Voice over guy can be annoying after the 3rd playthrough of a mission, some speeches are just so long XD
- That first gateway battle is brutal, I had an armada of 43 lvl 2 ants before I even came close to beating it, it did make me hate the scientist so I guess it was a success
- My computer overheated --> I'm sure that was my computers fault but it made the game unplayable past a certain level, maybe it was too many ants rendered? who knows ;_;

40741119.review:
Mal was neues: AMEISEN!

Netter EA-Titel. Startet schnell. 500-600 MB Download. Grafik absolut in Ordnung. Spiel macht Spaß. Steuerung problemlos. Keine Abstürze oder Ruckler, Spiel läuft sehr gut. Habe gleich auf Anhieb 11 Stunden gezockt. Das Spiel hat noch viel Potenzial. Anscheinend wurden wegen EA-Verkäufen jetzt 3 Entwickler fest angestellt.

Man darf gespannt sein! Von mir klare Kaufempfehlung. Es könnte aber 5 Euro günstiger sein.

Konstruktive Kritik muss auch bei EA-Titeln erlaubt sein.. hier ist was ich für verbesserungswürdig halte:

- Learning by doing kostet teilweise zu viele Ressourcen. Zum Beispiel die Aufteilung auf Soldaten und Arbeiter, oder welche Zellen man nebeneinander bauen muss um Boni zu erhalten. Das später umzubauen ist zu teuer!

- Zu wenig Karten, Missionen, Herausforderungen. Man baut seine Kolonie und startet von dort dann Missionen bzw. Herausforderungen. Mit den Belohnungen kann man seine Kolonie verbessern und ausbauen. Es gibt bisher nur 4 Missionen mit statischen Maps ( auswendig lernen ), die man immer wieder neu spielen kann oder muss. Dann gibts noch 2 Angriffswellen-Durchhaltemissionen für die eigene Kolonie. Und man kann die Waldameisen erforschen, aber das war es dann auch.

- Ameisen unterscheiden sich kaum. Die Spieler/Gegner erscheinen als blaue rote oder schwarze Ameisen, alle ziehmlich gleich groß. Es gibt Nah- und Fernkämpfer. Das wars. Man kann ihre Fähigkeiten ein bisschen aufwerten, aber das sind immer entweder-oder-Entscheidungen. Wenn man den Schlafplatz bzw. das Ei aufwerted, werden sie stärker ( und ich glaube größer ). Hört sich erstmal gut an, in der Praxis ist das aber alles etwas filigran, kaum sichtbar.

- Die Welt ist endlich und man bekommt häppchenweise Nachschub. Freies Spiel gibt es noch nicht, den Button im Spiel dafür aber schon. Nach 11 Stunden gibt es nichts mehr zu erkunden. Freies Spiel sollte Prio genießen..

- Updates. Veröffentlichung sollte 1.12. sein, wurde aber wohl auf 2.12. oder 3.12. verschoben. Da kam auch gleich ein Crash-Fix. Das ist jetzt 3,5 Monate her! Seither.. keine Updates mehr. Die Entwickler schreiben, sie möchten lieber größere und ausgereifte Updates veröffentlichen. Das ist löblich. Trotzdem sollte man als Spieler bei einem EA-Titel schon alle 1-2 Monate mal Veränderung sehen können.
