40480945.review:
Short summary: EotU is good, if very light on content at the moment. Anyone half decent at RTS or even just ressource management under pressure will get trough all avaiable missions in only a few hours, at which point the only replay-factor is doing challenge-variants of the missions or just cranking up the difficulty. Which means this is very much only a recommendation for those who are fine getting a fairly small amount of content in return for supporting further development.


Expanded: Many people compare this to SimAnt, and I cant give you a diret comparison here since I never played it and would assume that a game that old wont work on a new OS. What I CAN tell you is that Empires really nails the feel of growing an Ant colony, even if your current choices are rather limited.

You start a map with a Queen, capable of supporting around 7 workers by itself. From there you collect food, which can be spent to build nurseries which breed more ants. With the exception of the very first map (Which acts as a basic Tutorial) you are always under some form of time pressure. Sometimes it's rival ant colonies, other times it's just the other Insects, both of which either consider you a nuisance or food. 

As you might expect battles are won trough numbers. Meaning that you wll get annihilated rather quickly if you spend to much time not growing your army and workforce. Having few soldiers or spitters might mean death as soon as an attack rolls around. Having too little workers slows down food collection and thus hampers your growth and ability to stay competitive.

The game is actually quite challenging. I had to replay some of the campaign missions until I got a decent "build" down, and figured out roughly how much the game wants you to keep balance between army and workforce. Theres two difficulties above "normal", and altough I managed to complete most of the game on hard by this point, I'd say it becomes a little too stressful for me at this point, due to not having a whole lot of options.

Currently, you have worker ants, melee ants, and two kinds of ranged ants (One short ranged AoE and one rapid fire longer range) and that's basically it. Campaign missions have a set number of units avaiable, without any of the Upgrades you get in the Formicarium (Which acts as a sort of permanent hub and the place where you complete Challenges to open up more missions). And thus they are usually "solved" by knowing when to build what, and where the best food pockets are. Limited strategic options means that many of these missions will feel more like a puzzle, than actual RTS-style missions, which might not appeal to everybody.

Overall, EotU needs more content and more options, but offers a good few hours of fun or even more for those willing to replay some of it on higher and higher difficulties.

40384530.review:
Can't recommend it for now. Better wait for the final release. Aside from the modern graphics this is not on par with SimAnts yet, an ancient game decades old.

First of all ants: The gameplay isn't feeling as antsy or busy as you might think. There's too few ants overall with the current setup. They are also not doing well of displaying ant behavior. The ants will respond to pheromone markers you can set for them (not even a pheromone trail needed!) and run there like units in Starcraft. But like units in Starcraft they have no behaviour at all. They won't scout, do random stuff, they won't mess up - just act based on the markers. It's a sad sight to see really.
The game feels more like a tabletop game with dice roll mechanics and go-to, attack and defend obejectives. It's also very 2 dimensional. There's no 3d ant nest, just one tabletop platform for the overworld and the nest. You also can't build new walls or pile up surface nests - you can just dig away. That's not what ants do.

Gameplay is okay (not good) but has nothing to do with ants specifically. Aside from a skilltree there is no strategy involved at all. It's purely tactics. It's also the typical RTS setup - gather ressources, bunker or use them, expand, control units with attack markers.
There's nothing really antsy aside from the obvious ant-models (but they could easily be exchanged by dwarve models and have Zergs or another alien species attack them).
A grave error in my book is how the hex tile bonus is set up. Your colony, should you want it to be efficient, will look nothing like the screenshots. Those are super inefficient and will likely not even last you through the challenge waves.
The best way to build is sadly to just clean out giant chambers and set up the specific ant classes there since each tile get's a surrounding bonus. This way of brood management is so very not-ant-like I wonder why they came up with this.

AI is pretty much non-existent - ants will super block themselves in fights (great when the enemy has cleave) but due to the 2d setup won't even think of going around using walls or the non-existant ceiling.

Other points:
Updates are there but extremely slow.
The world itself looks and feels rather barren and lacks objects and more of an ant feel.
The sounds are also not very ant-like. More of a fantasy style with weird screems and growls.

Spoiler! [spoiler]I also HATE the story mode a bit. The sadistic scientist in the challenge waves throwing crazy numbers of hostile ants at your colony - with the innocent woman in the background chirping away happily.
Not only is this so much of a typical gender facepalm -  it's also VERY hard to believe that any sane and half-intelligent person wouldn't realize what he is / was doing.
It reminds me of those really bad stories in the news where mothers pretend they didn't know but in thuth just never bothered looking after the kids. It's disgusting really.
I don't find it funny, engaging or motivating. The opposite really.[/spoiler]

40192898.review:
At last, a spiritual successor to Sim Ant!

Empires of the Undergrowth is also hard as nails, and excellent fun.

Tired of building bases with towers and mining for resources? Yeah, me too. In EotU, your ants are the towers, and all your base really does is hatch new ants and store food, not much unlike an actual ant colony...

It's this simplicity that makes this game challenging; there's a fine balance between sending off your ants to die and gathering enough food to sustain an army during an attack. And yet, there's a skill tree for each type of ant, which ultimately sets up your colony to become a formidable force.

Four difficulty levels means there's lots of replayability (and you actually get more rewards the higher you go, so for once there's a real incentive for playing on Hard/Insane). There's even a humorous plotline, which was unexpected but appreciated.

Buy this game, you will not be disappointed.

40186555.review:
Depuis toujours, je suis passioné par un insecte : la fourmi. Elles ont leur propres technologies, armes, tactiques, etc. Cette passion vient du jeu Les Fourmis d'après le roman de Bernard Werber. Ce jeu m'a ensuite donné envie de lire le cycle des fourmis de Bernard Werber ([u]Les Fourmis[/u], [u]Le Jour des Fourmis[/u] et [u]La Révolution des Fourmis[/u]).
Quant j'ai vu Empires of the Undergrowth sur Steam Greenlight, j'ai tout de suite voté pour et je suivais le développement du jeu via les différentes vidéos des créateurs.
Actuellement le jeu comporte :
[list]
[*]les niveaux de la version de démo gratuite (disponible sur le siteweb du jeu) ;
[*]le mode Formicarium.
[/list]

Dans le mode Formicarium, on gère une colonie de Formica Ereptor dans un formicarium (vivarium adapté pour l'étude des fourmis) qui a la particularité de générer d'autres éspèces (comme des Formica fusca ou des Formica Rufa). On commence dans la fourmilière où on a un peu de nourriture à récolter. On peut utiliser cette nourriture pour améliorer la fourmilière (construction de salle pour déposer les œufs des différentes fourmis, construction de salle pour stocker plus de nourriture, etc). On peut creuser un accès pour allez à la surface du formicarium.
Les ressources vont commencer à manquer. Pour avoir de nouvelles ressources, des niveaux sont disponibles. Vous prendrer le contrôle d'une fourmilière d'une autre éspèce (on quitte le formicarium). Lorsque les objectifs sont réalisés, vous reprener le contrôle de votre colonie du formicarium. La nourriture gagnée par l'accomplissement du niveau apparaît à la surface.
Lorsque vous pensez que votre colonie est suffisament bien préparée, on peut commencer les différents challenges (2 actuellement mais une barre de progression montre 12 emplacements). Les personnes s'occupant du formicarium vont introduire des ennemis par vague d'assaut qu'il faudra vaincre.

Points positifs :
[list]
[*]une belle immersion dans le monde des fourmis ;
[*]plusieurs niveau de difficulté (plus vous mettez une difficulté élevé, plus vous aurez de ressource à la fin du niveau) ;
[*]la gestion de la fourmilière ne doit pas être négligée ;
[*]une option pour les arachnophobes (comme moi :D), ça rajoute un chapeau qui couvre la tête des araignées ;
[*]aucun, et je dis bien AUCUN bug rencontré ;
[*]pour les passionés ou les curieux sur les fourmis, c'est ici.
[/list]

Points négatifs :
[list]
[*]le jeu coûte 19,99€, pour le contenu actuel, ç'est un peu élevé (mais avec les prochains ajouts, ce point négatif disparaîtra ;
[*]pas de mode multijoueur (peut-être dans plusieurs update... qui pourrai être génial) ;
[*]pas de traduction française mais c'est facile à comprendre ce que les humains disent (pourtant je suis une quiche en anglais) (point négatif uniquement pour ceux qui ne comprenne rien de rien en anglais).
[/list]

Conclusion :
Un très bon jeu à acheter pour découvrir ou rédécouvrir le monde qui vit sous nos pieds, dont peu de gens s'en intéresse.

Bravo a Slug Disco et bonne continuation, ce jeu a atteint toutes mes attentes (à part pour le multi, mais ils avaient prévenu)

40165653.review:
Empires of the Undergrowth (EotU) is great in allowing you to grow your own ant colony.
At the moment there are not a whole lot of levels maps and gamemodes but I have been playing the demo for a while now and recently found out it was in early access on steam. The added things are simply great.

[i]Is it worth $20?[/i]
 
As of yet I'd say that I'm undecided. It's in early access and therefore of course it isn't a finished product and the content up to this point is not a lot. We have 9 maps to play on (including the formicarium) and 11 'missions' (maps and challenges). With about 12-15 hours you will have played everything at least once.

However, even though it isn't fully worth the $20 right now, I have full confidence it will be in the near future. 
The three man team is planning to all work full time on the game. Meaning that updates will be much quicker. 

[i]So what do we have and what is expected at this point?[/i]

Right now you can to start your own formicarium colony and do some great missions to develop them already. There are also individual mission and challenges.
The dev working on freeplay mode expects it to come out somewhere this month (february 2018) as he said in his last stream. 
It has been promised that you will be able to import a colony with the same traits as your formicarium colony (which you have to reseach) in the newsletter of january. If I believe I heard John correctly on his dev stream there will also be new formicarium levels somewhere later this year but they will appear in bulk. Meaning that it takes longer for them to come out but you will eventually end up with the same amount of levels. This was partly due to wanting to record the commentary in bulk so they won't have as many recording days if I heard it correctly.

[i]Should I buy the game?[/i]

If you're thinking about buying it eventually I'd personally say yes. (I did so. So, duh. Of course I'd say that, wouldn't want to make myself look stupid, would I?)
I'd say it is a better ant game than ant-sim simply because of differences in UI, graphics and substantial other gameplay elements. I feel more as if I am actually controlling the ants.

Wether you want to wait untill freeplay or some more content in the form of formicarium challenges or want to start playing and grinding for that sweet royal jelly now is up to you.

[b][i]General opinion[/i][/b]

I really enjoy the EotU at the moment. The gameplay is great, so is the UI. Maybe the little pop-up things with info should be changed a little since they are easy to miss for a first time player which could put them off. But then again, players who know how the game works and don't need them can ignore them easily. So maybe put those info panels on how to play as an option.
I also really enjoy the documentary style of commentary used. Generally, I like the way I see the game going at this point.

It maybe an idea to start developing a way for players to start creating new freeplay maps. Similarly to the way Company of Heroes has it with a simple map editor (similar to what John uses in the current Dunes map). It would be a great way to get a vast amount of content in a relatively short period since, like I said, the dev team is rather small.



TL;DR
The game is great, but right now it suffers from a lack of things to do (content). Luckily that will most likely be fixed relatively soon. It's relaxing on easy and medium, actually gets hard on hard and I don't even want to attempt challenging. I'm very anthausiastic about what this game will be.

I wish the devs the best of luck, may they bring us more content soon!

39851117.review:
This is a great game and one I personally backed. I'm a fan of ants and this is the perfect thing I needed. The game is similar to Dungeon Keeper but has its own feeling to it, you have your queen that lays eggs and needs tending to. You build your colony up and face whatever challenges await you. From clearing out your nest from vermin beetles to surviving two approaching colonies that are going to be knocked out by a tidal wave. After you finish a mission you go to your formicarium aka your hub. You spend the your resources such as food, territory, and royal jelly to grow your army.

I've active on the games forum and its a lively community where you can suggest ideas and debate about topics. The devs do streams on Twitch that are a pleasure to watch. There are very few bugs but when they occur they are minor. I do have a few gripes though, I think that there should be more types of insects like say black widows and assassin beetles. I feel that you can do very little to decorate your nest, and why isn't there more human garbage. These are pretty small gripes though but I have to say there isn't much content but the value of the content is high. The next few updates will have more levels though. Speaking of that, there is gonna be a freeplay mode. If I had to rate this I would give it a 8.5/10
